abstract.text: An object that represents a collection of record zones and subscriptions.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A database takes requests and operations and applies them to the objects it contains, whether that’s record zones, records, or subscriptions. Each of your app’s users has access to the three separate databases:
A public database that’s accessible to all users of your app.
A private database that’s accessible only to the user of the current device.
A shared database that’s accessible only to the user of the current device, which contains records that other iCloud users share with them.

The public database is always available, even when the device doesn’t have an active iCloud account. In this scenario, your app can fetch specific records and perform searches, but it can’t create or modify records. CloudKit requires an iCloud account for writing to the public database so it can identify the authors of any changes. All access to the private and shared databases requires an iCloud account.
, nor do you subclass it. Instead, you access the required database using one of your app’s containers. For more information, see

method and provide the configuration and a trailing closure.
In the closure, use the provided database to execute the relevant methods at the preferred QoS.

abstract.text: Store structured app and user data in iCloud containers that all users of your app can share.
A conduit to your app’s databases.

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
